content: #28710 makes MulEquivClass an abbrev of MulHomClass. Should we simply drop MulEquivClass?
@Junyan Xu why? i'm very confused here
Apparently this is some leftover from #8386; cc @Anne Baanen
I have an old PR #18806 that deprecates MulEquivClass.
Looks nice! If Anne approves of this change and you upgrade your PR to the current master, I'll close my PR.

I think this is a good idea overall, if we can figure out the downstream consequences: Are we going to do the same for other equivs, like docs#SemilinearEquivClass -> docs#SemilinearMapClass (I assume so)? How do we then deal with docs#RingEquivClass which has fewer proof obligations than docs#RingHomClass? (For example: we define AddMulHomClass which is the intersection of AddHomClass and MulHomClass, and then say abbrev RingEquivClass := AddMulHomClass.)

Yeah I agree with replacing SemilinearEquivClass by SemilinearMapClass (this is probably also a leftover from the unbundling refactor), and introducing AddMulHomClass (basically what I also suggest here).

In fact why don't we break everything down to the four classes Mul/Add/One/ZeroHomClass. We won't ever need to make the rest of the 2^4-1=15 possible combinations classes then. SemilinearMapClass is naturally broken down into AddHomClass and MulActionSemiHomClass.
The other families of classes like docs#SubmonoidClass can be similarly broken down; not sure about the performance impact.
Currently because of this issue, docs#SemilinearMapClass cannot be broken down.
